The time period during which tensions in the Middle East resurfaced and public skepticism about the Gaza deal intensified, undermining any perceived diplomatic success.

keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for President Donald Trump’s handling of the Gaza ceasefire deal, despite its global visibility.
Trump’s approval ratings on Gaza increased slightly (from 37% to 47% in AP-NORC poll), but disapproval remains high at 49%, indicating limited public support.
Trump’s overall approval rating reached a second-term low at 37% approving, 61% disapproving, reflecting a deepening political unpopularity.
A CNBC poll shows Trump is disapproved of 52% on the economy and 50% on Gaza, highlighting a major disconnect between international diplomacy and domestic concerns.

Americans are increasingly disapproving of Trump’s economic policies, particularly inflation and cost of living, with 62% disapproving of his inflation handling and a 13-point deficit in economic approval.
Public pessimism is rising: only 32% of Americans expect the economy to improve in the next year, and only 31% expect their wages to rise.
Employed Americans are increasingly worried about job loss, with only 52% saying they are not at all worried — a decline from previous years.
Foreign policy is low on the public priority list; only 4% of Americans in a CBS News-YouGov poll ranked international events as the most important issue.
Three-fourths of Americans believe Trump has not focused enough on lowering prices, indicating economic concerns outweigh foreign policy achievements.
The public’s skepticism of Trump’s Gaza deal reflects broader distrust in foreign policy successes, especially after the short-lived Biden-era ceasefire.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the announcement of a Gaza ceasefire deal, President Donald Trump faces minimal public support in the United States, with his approval ratings on both the deal and domestic issues remaining low. While one poll shows a slight improvement in approval on Gaza, disapproval remains high, and overall approval is at a second-term low. Economic concerns — including inflation, rising costs of living, and job insecurity — are now the dominant public issues, with a majority of Americans disapproving of Trump’s economic leadership and expressing pessimism about the future of the economy. Public skepticism about foreign policy successes is amplified by the short-lived nature of previous peace efforts, such as the Biden administration’s ceasefire. Americans prioritize domestic economic well-being over international diplomacy, suggesting that Trump’s global achievements are not translating into political capital at home.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
